SQL Database

It can store large amounts of data, create and arrange periodic synchronizations between your Cloud SQL Database and local SQL Server or other SQL Database instances.

Apply for a trial Buy Now

Azure SQL Database is a cloud database service built for application developers. The database is a unique service that allows real-time scaling without downtime, helps you to efficiently deliver multi-tenant applications, and further enables you more time to innovate and release products to the market at a faster speed. The built-in intelligence of the SQL Database will quickly understand the unique characteristics of the application and dynamically adjust it to maximize its performance, reliability, and data protection capabilities. You can use a language and platform you like to generate secure applications which shall be connected to an SQL Database.

An Elastic Database is a shared resource model that increases resource utilization efficiency. All databases in an elastic pool share predefined resources in the same pool. The workload pattern is well-defined and extremely cost-effective in multi-tenant scenarios. An elastic pool is best suited to new SaaS applications or upgrading existing applications to SaaS.

If flexible, controllable, and transparent independent resource usage is required, a vCore-based purchasing model is most suitable. This model allows calculation scaling, memory, and storage based on workload requirements and provides a direct way to translate local workload requirements into the cloud. The vCore model is in preview. The price reflects the cost of the official version.

Elastic Database Model

When using an Elastic Database pool, you can manage the overall properties of the pool (instead of a single database). The databases in the pool are called elastic databases, which can automatically increase or decrease to meet demands. Databases can be easily added to or deleted from the pool, scaling the databases of an application from a small number to thousands with all costs not exceeding the budget that you control.

Elastic database pools are available in Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers. Each tier is distinguished mainly by its overall performance measured in Elastic Database Transaction Units (eDTU). Please refer to Elastic Database Pool Service Tiers for further information. The Elastic Database Model has been officially released online. Customers will continue to enjoy a discount price of 50% for preview versions.

Active Geo-replication

Active Geo-replication can create up to 4 online (readable) secondary databases in any Azure region. The secondary database can be created using the same service level as the primary database, with some potential differences in performance. The secondary database is priced at 1 times the price of the selected performance level. The traffic costs arising from Geo-replication between the primary and secondary databases are included in the costs of the online secondary database.

FAQ

Expand All
  • What is a vCore?

    A virtual core (vCore) represents the logical CPUs available to the server. Customers can choose between two generations of hardware. For servers created using the Gen4 vCore, the vCore is based on the Intel E5-2673 v3 (Haswell) 2.4 GHz processor.

  • What are the advantages of a vCore-based model?

    With a vCore-based purchasing model, local workload requirements can be translated to the cloud in a flexible, controlled, and direct manner. This allows independent scaling of calculation and storage resources based on workload requirements.

    A vCore-based model is suitable for SQL Database Managed Instances, single databases, and elastic pool deployment options. These options all use Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server. Therefore, pricing within a vCore-based model applies whether or not you use Hybrid Benefit:

    • Licenses included: Does not include Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server. This option is suitable for customers who are reluctant to apply existing SQL Server licenses with Software Assurance to vCore-based database deployment options.
    • Baseline rate: Discount price that includes Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server. Customers can choose this price by using an SQL Server license with Software Assurance.
  • Do I have to move to a vCore-based model?

    You don’t need to move to a vCore-based model. The introduction of vCore-based deployment options for elastic pools and single databases embodies our commitment to customer choice and flexibility. If you wish to continue using a DTU-based model, no action is required and your experience and billing methods will remain the same. In addition to vCore-based models, a DTU-based model is still a viable option for purchasing SQL Database.

  • What will happen to DTU-based models?

    DTU- and vCore-based models will continue to coexist. We launched vCore-based models at the request of our customers. These customers want to get greater transparency for database resources and scale computing and storage separately. Using a vCore-based model, customers with active Software Assurance can also save costs via Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server.

  • How should I choose between a DTU- or vCore-based model?

    Data transfer units (DTU) are based on a mixture of CPU, memory, read, and write measurements. DTU-based performance levels represent provisioned resource bundles that drive different levels of application performance. If you do not want to worry about underlying resources, and want to use a simple provisioned bundle and pay a fixed monthly fee, a DTU-based model may better meet your needs.

    If you need to learn more about underlying resources, or scale them independently for optimum performance, the best choice is to continue with a vCore model. In addition, if you activate Software Assurance (SA) for SQL Server, you can leverage existing investments and save 30% on costs through Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server. Both purchasing models can offer benefits for fully managed services, such as automated backups, software updates, and patches.

  • Do I need to take my application offline to convert from a DTU-based database to a vCore-based service tier?

    The new service tiers offer a simple online dialog method that is similar to the existing process for upgrading databases from the Standard to the Premium service tier and vice versa. The portal can be launched using Portal, ARM, PowerShell, Azure CLI or T-SQL.

  • How does usage show up on my bill?

    In a vCore-based model, the service is billed at a predictable, hourly rate based on the provisioned compute in vCores, provisioned storage (in GB/month), and backup storage used. There will be additional charges if backup exceeds the total database size (that is, 100% of the database size). vCore hours, configured database storage, consumed IO, and backup storage are itemized on the bill, making it easier for you to see the details of resources you have used. Backup storage of up to 100% of the maximum database size is included, beyond which you are billed for GB/month.

    For example:

    • If an SQL Database exists for 12 hours in a month, the bill will show the cost for 12 hours of vCore usage. If the SQL Database provisioned an additional 100 GB of storage, the bill will show storage usage in units of GB/month prorated hourly and the number of IOs consumed in a month.

    If the uptime of an SQL Database is less than 1 hour, the costs for each hour the database exists are calculated using the highest service tier, provisioned storage, and IO that were used during that hour, regardless of usage or whether the database uptime was less than an hour.

    For example:

    • If you create a Managed Instance and delete it five minutes later, you’ll be charged for 1 database hour.
    • If you create a Managed Instance in the General Purpose tier with 8 vCores, then immediately upgrade it to 16 vCores, you’ll be charged at the 16 vCore rate for the first hour.

    Please Note: For a limited period before June 30, 2018, backup and IO are free of charge.

  • Do I need to bear any network data transfer costs?

    There will be no additional charges for the entry or exit of network data during the public preview. Additional fees will be charged after the official release.

  • What is Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server? Am I eligible to use it?

    Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server can help you to maximize the value of your current license investment and accelerate migration to the cloud. Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server is an Azure-based hybrid benefit. An SQL Server license with Software Assurance can be used through it in order to pay less SQL Database charges (baseline rate). All vCore-based options can be used via Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server: SQL Database Managed Instances, single databases, and elastic pools. You can apply this benefit even if SKUs are active, but please note that the baseline rate will be applied from when you make a selection in the portal. The credit limit will not be reissued.

    You can activate Azure Hybrid Benefit by proving that you have a valid license with Software Assurance in the Azure portal. The working principles for Azure Hybrid Benefit are as follows:

    • If you have the Standard Edition with Software Assurance, issued per core license, choose the General Purpose option and get 1 vCore for every 1 local license core.
    • If you have the Enterprise Edition with Software Assurance, issued per core license, select the Business-Critical option (coming soon) and get 1 vCore for every 1 local license core. Note: The Business-Critical option for Azure Hybrid Benefit for SQL Server is only offered to Enterprise Edition customers.
    • If you have the highly-virtualized Enterprise Edition with Software Assurance, issued per core license, choose the General Purpose option and get 4 vCores for every 1 local license core. This is a unique virtualization benefit that is limited to Azure.
  • What are virtualization benefits?

    Virtualization benefits apply to virtualized workloads on vCore-based Azure SQL Databases. Use them to convert 1 SQL Enterprise Edition license core through valid Software Assurance to get up to 4 managed instance General Purpose vCores at the baseline rate. This is a cost-effective way to migrate virtualized applications to vCore-based SQL Databases. For example, if you have 4 core licenses for SQL Enterprise Edition, you can get up to 16 General Purpose vCores at the baseline rate.

  • Can I use an SQL Server license on-premises and in the cloud?

    The license must be used on-premises or in the cloud, but there is a grace period of 180 days during which the license can be used both on-premises and in the cloud to facilitate migration.

If you have any questions or need help, please visit Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

Basic, Standard, and Premium Levels

We guarantee a connection time between a single or elastic Basic, Standard or Premium Azure SQL Database and our Internet Gateway of not less than a 99.99%.
